title: 108_hr3972
content:
The Act titled "Protecting Our Children from Violence Act of 2004" allows state social services officers access to federal databases for specific purposes. The "Protecting Our Children from Violence Act of 2004" grants state social services officers online access to federal criminal databases for conducting criminal history records checks on individuals who resided with a minor. The Act allows state social services officers to conduct criminal history checks on individuals who resided with a minor during incidents of abuse or neglect. The Attorney General ensures that state social services officers have "read only" electronic access to the National Crime Information Center for conducting checks on missing persons. State social service officers have "read only" electronic access to the National Crime Information Center for investigating missing children and sharing information with law enforcement agencies. State social service officers can gain access to the National Crime Information Center by submitting a certification to the Attorney General through their state agency. The certification must confirm the officer's role, direct charge over minors in the child welfare system, suitability for the authority granted, and meeting all Federal access standards. State social service officers can access the National Crime Information Center by submitting a certification to the Attorney General through their state agency. The certification must confirm the officer's role, direct charge over minors in the child welfare system, suitability for the authority granted, and meeting all Federal access standards, including training, certification, and background screening. The term "control terminal agency" refers to a duly authorized criminal justice agency with direct access to the National Crime Information Center telecommunications network. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories, providing services to criminal justice users managed by the FBI's Criminal Justice Information Services Division. SEC. 3. ACCESS TO III BY NATIONAL CENTER FOR MISSING AND EXPLOITED CHILDREN. The Attorney General ensures access to the Interstate Identification Index for specific divisions of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, with officers meeting Federal standards for access. SEC. 4. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. (a) Information from checks or access under sections 2 and 3 must not be altered except for national security reasons.
(b) Information can only be shared with other authorized officers or employees. The information obtained from checks or access under sections 2 and 3 must not be altered except for national security reasons. It can only be shared with authorized officers, employees, or persons authorized by law. Any person who knowingly releases information in violation of this rule may face criminal penalties of up to 1 year imprisonment or fines under title 18, United States Code.
